document.text: Winners in the Football Contest sponsored by local m erchants have been an nounced by the TIMES-VIR- GINIAN for the contest in the November 2, 1978 edition of this newspaper. Jefferson Forest - William Campbell did not play each other in Friday nights game so we will not count that as one of the contest games. With a possible 22 correct predictions to make in this contest, Raymond W. Bryant of Route 3, Appomattox correctly picked 21 games. He is winner of first place and will receive a check from the TIMES-VIR-  GINIAN in the. amount of 10.00 as first place prize. Correctly picking 20 of the games from the possible 22  games listed in the contest were Nelwyn Morris of Route 3, Robert I. Scott of 510 Virginia Avenue, Leoh Bryant, Jr. of Route 3, and Steve Mitchell of P. 0. Box 132. Going to the tie-breakers for a winner, Steve Mitchell was the only one of the four to pick Air Force to beat Army which was incorrect. Going to the Appo mattox - Amherst game for a winner, Robert I. Scott with an 8 point difference in the game is winner of second place and will receive a check. from the TIMES-VIRGINIAN in the amount of 5.00 as second place prize. Appomattox won over Amherst by only 2 points. As this was the last game of the season for the Seminole District, of which Appomattox Raiders are Champions, the -frxA bottcontegt W itt  k UrtWrt until next season. Congratula tions to all the winners and to the participants in the contest this year. It truly created a great deal of interest.

document.text: The Raiders had an outstand ing fourth quarter on Tuesday night, Dee. 21, when they scrired 21 points and beat the Altavista Colonels60-55. The game was played at Altavista after the V anity Girls game. The Raiders led the first quarter with twelve points to a Colonel nine. Both teams scored fifteen points in thé second quarter to make thé score at the half, 27 to 24. The Raiders slacked off in scoring during thé third quarter and the Colonels took a one point lead after scoring sixteen pointa. The Raiden only had twelve points in the third quarter and at the beginning of the fourth quarter the score was 40 to 39, Colonels leading. The Raiders scored 21 points in the fourth quarter and cut short the Colbnels hopes for victory. The find score was 55 to 60, the Appomattox Raiders on top. Mitch Eggleston and Bill Shorter scored up in the double figures - Mitch with 17 and Bill with 10. Tom Wingfield had eight points, ftonald Harvey had seven, James Robinson had six, and Gerald Booker had four. Joe Fraley ad Cecil Booker both added three points on the Raider score, and Tony Snell had two. For the Colonels, Tracy Poindexter had 24 points, E rrette Woodruff had 10, and no other Colonel scored in the double figures for the night. The Tuesday night game brought the Raiders to a 2 win, 3 loss situation while the Colonels are now 0 for 6. The Raiders had an excellent night from thé foul line, with a g62 precent average. The  Altavista team had a commen- I dable 44 percent, g The R aiders travel to g Jefferson Forest the 28th of  December for their last game of 76. In overall district stand ings, the Raiders are in 6th place and Jefferson Forest is 7th. Come on out and cheer t Raiders to victory!!!

document.text: The Raider varsity basketball team lifted their district record to 10-6 last Tuesday with a 61-50 win over Liberty. The Raiders took the lead in the first quarter, leading 16-12 at the end of that period. In the second period. Liberty outscored the Raiders 16-10 to take a 28-26 lead into the locker room at the half. . The Raiders virtually shut down the Liberty offense in the third quarter, allowing Liberty only four points the entire period, while putting 14 on the board for themselves. Appomattox outscored Liberty 21-18 in the final period of play to ice the victory, 61-50. Rick Caldwell led Raider scorers with 17 points, including 15 in the fourth quarter. Jeff Miller also scored in double figures for the Raiders, with 15 points. M iller also added 12 rebounds to the Appomatox effort. Others scoring for the Raiders were Gary Fergus nine points, Ricky Miller eight points, Darwin Harvey eight points, Bobby Carter and Mike Jackson, with two points each. C arter also had eight rebounds for the Raiders. Appomattox hit 24 field goals and went 13 for 18 from the foul line against Liberty. .Liberty hit 22 field gods and was successful on six of sixffreethrow attempts. High scorers for Liberty -were Marvin Evans 12 points and Clarence Robinson 10 points. The Raiders were scheduled to day Rustburg at home Wednesday ana will travel to Buckingham Friday night. The Seminole District tournament is scheduled to b egin next Tuesday. Feb. 22 and will continue through Saturday. The tournament wOl be played at Rustburg High School.

document.text: The Nelson County Gover nors scored the first time they had the ball and then added another quick score in the sec ond quarter to beat the favor ed Appomattox Raiders 13-7 in a Seminole District football game last Saturday night at Appomattox. The lost gave the Raiders a 3-2 mark overall. Nelson County took the opening kickoff and started on their own 29 yard line and in 13 plays they went the 71 yards for the score, all on the ground. Beany C a m p b e l l scored the touchdown from one yard out with 541 left in the quarter. The extra point try failed and it was 6-0 Nelson. The Raiders took the lead in the second quarter as the  result of a 73 yard drive in six plays with quarterback Bobby Layne going the last five yards for the touchdown. Phillip Goode kicked the extra point  for a 7-6 Raider lead with 844 left in the half. Appomattox kicked off and Nelson returned it to their own 45 yard line. Campbell carried five yards and then Larry Rose on the next play went 50 yards for a score with 739 left in the half and Knight kicked the extra point for a 13-7 lead. Nelson had the ball on the one foot line as the half ended ready to score again but time ran out. The second half was mostly defense as the teams would get a first down or two and then have to punt. Larry Rose was the top ball carrier for Nelson with 154 yards rushing in 20 carries. Campbell had 81 and Ragland 58 to account for the total yards on the ground for them. document.text: The first place Appomattox Raiders will host the Jefferson Forest Caveliers in the annual homecoming game this Friday at 800 p.m. in Bragg Stadium. The Cavaliers bout a 4 and 2 Seminole District record and will be a tough opponent for the Raiders who are coming off a big win against Brookville last week. Raider Head Coach Stuart Justus is concerned about Jefferson Forest who he describes as big and _ in possession of a fast running back by the name of Jefferson. The Cavaliers have just two seniors in their starting offensive lineup but they cannot be taken lightly. The Raiders, who must win to remain in first place, will be looking for an overflow crowd for file 1978 Homecoming.

document.text: The Appomattox Raiders we athered a strong second-half comeback by a scrappy Randoiph- Henry team to preserve a 28-22 non-district victory in the Raiders second game of this season Friday night. Raider quarterback Paul Johnson got the Appomattox teams initial six points in the first quarter on a one-yard plunge into the Randoiph- Henry end zone. The point-after touchdown kick by Kevin Kendrick was unsuccessful. The rest of the evenings scoring for the Raiders came compliments of Steve Boo Hamlett, the Raiders lightening-quick tailback. Hamlett scored on runs of three yards and one yard in the second quarter, and on a five-yard scamper in the third qiuurter. The Raiders got two points on a conversion pass from Johnson to Tyrone Abbitt, and two more on conversion kicks by Kendrick. Randoiph-Henry began to battle back, scoring late in the second quarter, and carrying the momen tum of that score with them through half time and into the second half. The Statesmen used a mixture of well-executed pass plays and quick hitting running plays to whittle away at the Appomattox lead. Randoiph-Henry scored twice in the third quarter and appeared on the- way to a fourth score in the final period of play, but the Raider defense utilized opportunities such as fumble recoveries and intercep tions to halt the Statesmens momentum. document.text: The Appomattox Raiders took part in the William Byrd Christmas Invitational Basket ball Tournament last week end in Vinton and came home a winner. The Raiders had to fight back in an overtime period to beat Glenvar in the opening round 76-74 on Thursday night and then took Lord Botetourt 73-47 in the championship game on Friday night. The win Friday night ran the Appomattox record to 7-0 overall. In Thursdays night game  against Glenvar, the Raiders led 21-20 at the end of the first quarter, 42-33 at the half and trailed 55-52 at the end of the third quarter. It was tied at 70-70 at the end of the regulation time. Appomattox led by as much as 13 points in the second quarter, but Glenvar hit on 11 of 15 shots from the floor in the third quarter for 22 points while the Raiders went cold and got only ten points in that quarter. In the first quarter Bobby Layne got 12 of the Raiders 21 points as he hit five for five from the floor and two foul shots. Mark Eggleston, the Raiders sixth man, came off the bench and finished the game with 13 points, nine in the second half, and gave the Raiders a big four point lead in the overtime as he made two foul shots with 15 seconds left in the game. Dennis Totty and Sammy Waddell had the other two baskets in the overtime, both hitting on clutch shots. Layne led the Raiders with 22 points and big Leon Robinson had 19 points and 15 rebounds. Eggleston was next with 13, Sammy Waddell had eight and Dennis Totty had seven along with Kenneth Gafford. Totty also had eight rebounds. document.text: The Appomattox Raiders is one of the finest basketball teams that I have ever seen. To have such a winning season as the Raiders are enjoying there has to be basketball know-how, training, teamwork, skill, and tremendous motiva tion. Their coach has done a good job of injecting all of this into these players week by week. The Raiders train in their gym that is located at Appo mattox County High School. They have viewed films, ex ercised, studied, and practiced the fine art of teamwork. Their basketball experiences are not confined just to that gym. They have to get out into the gyms of this entire area and play the game for real. Our church house is located at 100 Church Street and is a lot like the training area for the Raiders. At the church house we learn how God expects us to serve him as we study the Bible. We learn from others how they are doing the job. We fellowship with other Christians and develop team spirit. Unfortunately, many limit their Christian activity to their experiences only at the church house. They completely misunderstand the work of the church in organizing training, and preparing Christians for their part in the game of life throughout this entire area. document.text: The Appomattox Raiders got by a shaky start and had a big second quarter and went on to beat the Staunton River Gold en Eagles 73-64 last Tuesday night in a Seminole District basketball game played at Staunton River. The win gives the Raiders a 5-0 mark overall and 4-0 in the district. Staunton River got off to a 13-12 lead in the first quarter, but a 25 point second quarter for the Raiders gave them a 40-28 halftime lead. Appomat tox made it 59-42 after three quarters and the reserves saw a lot of action then. The Raiders controlled the rebounds as they pulled down 45 to 24 for the Golden Eagles and the Raiders shot a hot 48 from the floor to a not so bad 44 for Staunton River. Bobby Layne led the Raiders in scoring with 18 points and played a good defensive game also. He was followed by Leon Robinson with 14 points and also 14 rebounds and Kenneth Gaffordk had 11 to round out the double figure men for Appomattox. Ricky Morgan led the Golden Eagles and was also game top scorer with 23 points. He was closely followed by Dave Nichols with 22 and Calvin Holdren with 10. Dennis Totty proved to be one of the top rebounders for the Raiders in helping them control the boards. In the shooting, both Robinson and Layne shot over 50 from the floor. The Raiders had 15 turn overs while the Golden Eagles had 12. The Raiders will play December the 28th and 29th in a Christmas Tournament Roanoke at 8 p.m.

document.text: The Appomattox Raiders built up a 10 point first quarter lead and went on to beat the Nelson County Governors by the same margin, 63-53 last Friday night in a Seminole District basketball game play ed at Nelson. The win gives the Raiders a 12-1 mark overall and a 9-0 record in the district. The lost dropped Nelson to 8-6 overall and 7-4 in district. The Raiders got off to a 19-9 lead in the first quarter, but it was 30-24 at the half as Nelson outscored the Raiders 15-11 in that quarter. The Raiders then outscored Nelson 14-7 in the third quarter for a 13 point lead, 44-31, going into the last quarter. William Napper, the districts leading scorer, continued his scoring ways as he ripped the nets for 32 points, 16 in the last quarter, to take game honors. Keith Haywood added 13 as the only other Nelson player to hit in double figures. They conbined for 45 of the Governors points. document.text: The Appomattox Raiders beat the Gretna Hawks 52-39 last Friday night in a Seminole District basketball game play ed at Appomattox. The victory gives the Raiders a 7-0 mark in the district and 10-1 overall. They lead the district while Gretna dropped to fifth place with a 5-3 league mark and 6-5 overall. The Hawks tried a slow down brand of play and it i seemed to work for the first  half as the score was tied 10-10  after a quarter of play and the I Raiders only led by two, 19 17 at the half. In the second half the slow down game changed a  little as the Raiders made the j Hawks make mistakes and took advantage of them for a 31-23 lead at the end of the third quarter. This led to more Hawk mistakes as they had to play catch-up ball and Appo- mattox kept taking advantage of them and outscored the Hawks 21-16 in the last quarter. Bobby Layne led the Raiders and all scorers with 24 points, 15 in the second half as he hit I seven of nine from the floor,  five of five in the last quarter. Leon Robinson was the only other Raider in double figures with 16, 10 coming in the last quarter as he and Layne com bined to score all 21 of the Raider points. The Raiders hit 50 from the floor, 23 of 46 shots to 40 for the Hawks who hit on 17 of 42 attempts. document.text: Some questionable calls from the officials and a couple of poorly executed plays may have cost the Appomattox Raiders third place in the Seminole District football race as they dropped a 14-6 decision to Rustburg Friday night. The Red Devils scored in the second quarter on a 56 yard pass from Kenneth Tweedy to James Trent, and in the fourth quarter Mark Wright threw a six yard scoring strike to Gary Anthony. Wright then passed to Willie Clark for the two point conversion. The Raiders only score came a 58 yard pass from Mac Weaver to Ricky Wingfield on the first play from scrimmage following Rustburgs second touchdown. . Coach Jerry Robinson said, I would just like to have one over. I called a pass play on a second down and three situation. I think the play was but it was not executed very well and Rustburg intercepted. I gave that a lot of thought over the week end and I probably would have called the same play anyway, but I would just like to have the . chance to run it over. Robinson declined to com ment on the role the officials played in the contest, saying only, Both teams were hurt by penalties. I thought there were to many flags thrown all night, but I cant say that we were hurt any more than Rustburg was. Actually there were two very questionable plays. document.text: Russell Henderson unleashed an air attack against the Appomattox Raiders which carried the Amherst Lancers to a 26-6 Seminole District foot ball win Friday night. The 6-3, 195 pound senior completed 15 of 26 passes for 129 yards and two touchdowns as the Raiders defensive unit refused to yield to the usually potent ground game of the Lancers. The Raiders only score came on a 12 yard pass from Mac Weaver to Ricky Wingfield with just six seconds left to play in the game. Prior to the touchdown drive, Appomattox crossed midfield only once when Weaver passed 15 yards to Wingfield for a first down on the Amherst 48. The drive stalled there as three passes fell incomplete and Mitch Eggleston was forced to punt on the fourth down. Amherst scored with 328 left in the first period when Ricky Simmons was caught in his own end zone by Donnie Sandidge. The Raiders had just piade a goal line stand to deny Amherst a touchdown as Flip Jamersonand Warren Coleman stopped Russell Agnew for a two yard losses on a fourth down and goal to go situation from the one yard line. With 734 left in the half, Amherst finally got its first touchdown when Larry Hughes scampered 20 yards on a double reverse that caught the Appo- mattox defenders moving away from the football. document.text: Chatham Edges Raiders 64-56 In Finals The Chatham Cavaliers broke a 54-54 tie with about four min utes left in the game and went on to beat the Appomattox Raiders 64-56 in the finals of the Group AA, Region III basketball tour nament held at Lynchburg Col lege last Saturday night. The win made Chatham 20-3 as they go to the State tournament and Appomattox finished with a 18-6 record for the season as they got the runner-up trophy for the tournament. The game was tied five times in the first quarter with the Raiders out in front 18-17 as the buzzer sounded. The Raid ers had a 11-7 lead for the big gest spread in that quarter. It was tied three times in the sec ond quarter, the last at 31-31, before Chatham scored at the buzzer for a 33-31 half time lead. Sammy Waddell kept the Raiders in the game in the third quarter as he hit for six points and they tied it at 46-46 going into the last quarter. Chatham built a eight point lead, 43-35, in that quarter but David John son hit with less than a minute in the quarter to tie it a 44-44 before each team scored again. In the fourth quarter, the score was tied at 54-54 with about four minutes left in the game and the Raiders went cold and could not try a basket as Chatham run to a 64-54 lead in that span. The last two Raider points came at the game ending buzzer as Leon Robinson tapped in a missed shot. Chatham hit six f r e e throws in the last of the game as the Raiders fouled to get the ball. Ricky Garrett, a senior play ing his last game for the Raid ers, led them with 15 points and four assist to go along with eight rebounds. He was followed by Leon Robinson and Sammy Wad dell with 12 points each. Robin son had 10 rebounds and hit six of nine from the floor and Wad dell hit six of 10 attempts. Thomas Motley led a scorers with 27 points as most of them came close under the basket. He had 16 in the first half. He was followed by John Waller with 24 as he hit 10 of 15 shot from the floor, mostly outside jumpers.

document.text: by Tommy Pittman On the Appomattox Raiders 1974 football team the starting offensive center and defensive right tackle spots are manned by senior Mike Ramsey, an athlete who is also one of the leading students academically at ACHS. Mike 6-0, 183 was an All-District Honorable Men tion performer last year and seems to be as good, or better, this year. He, along with three1 other local students, was recently named a National i Merit Commended Scholar. Mike also is listed in Whos Who Among High School Students. Ramsey, the son of Mrs. Anne L. Ramsey of Hunter Street, Appomattox, is in his fifth year of Raider football and  third as a varsity starter. He has managed the varsity basketball team in the past and  will do so again this year. As a track man in his third year, Mike is a capable shotputter j and discus thrower. Mike takes an advanced course of study and does very well. His subjects this year are government, English, physics and college math, in which he received two As and two Bs. He also received an A for assisting coaches Bragg and Dickerson in sixth period P.E. Extracurricular activities are very important to Mike. In addition to football, basketball and track, he is president of the Varsity Club and a member of the National Honor Society. Mike has set his goals high, as a student of his ability should he says he plans to major in engineering at either Virginia Tech or Georgia Tech. document.text: By Tamara Nub On Tuesday night, December 7, the Appomattox Raiders traveled to Gretna for their first district game and H ud victorious with a score of 51-47. The Raiders were dominant over the Hawks in the first half as far as scoring went and the score was 26-16 at the half. The Hawks led the Raiders in second-half scoring by scoring 31 points to a Raider 25. Still, the Varsity Raiders held fast and won the game with a four point margin. Co-captain Mitch Eggleston led the Raiders in scoring with 20 points, Ronald Harvey eras second with 11, James Robin son and Bill Shorter each had 8 points, and Joe Fraley and Tommy Wingfield each had 2. Co-captains, Mitch Eggleston and Jam es Robinson and center, Bill Shorter led the team in Rebounds. Eggleston had 14, Robinson and Shorter both had 9 off the boards. The Raiders had a 49 shooting game from the floor. The big Hawks player of the night was 10,. Miller, who scored a total of 23 points, 16 of these points coming in the last half of the game. No other Gretna player scored over 10 points and it was a defeated Hawks team that left their home court Tuesday night. The Raiders are off to a winning season and they need the support of you, so come out and support your 1 Raider team. Be a 1 Raider fan!

document.text: by Joe Vaughan The Appomattox Raiders traveled to Nelson last Friday night, only to suffer a defeat, as they were overcome 95-59. Things got off to a bad start for the Raiders, as they could only score six points in the first quarter, opposed to Nelsons 35. Appomattox came back in the second quarter to get 26 points, while Nelson scored 23, but as halftime began, the scoreboard showed Nelson with 58, and Appomattox with 32. In the third quarter, the Raiders were only able to get 12 points. As the third quarter ended Appomattox was behind by a big margin of 34 points, with the score 78-44. The Raiders were held to 15 points in the fourth quarter, which wasnt enough to make ends meet. This was the second loss to Nelson by the Raiders this season. Leading scorer for Appomat tox was Enoch Robinson, who scored 15 points. Following behind him were Mitch Eggles ton with 10, Hal Smith with 9, Dickie Kelso with 7, and Tommy Turkey Wingfield with 6. The Raiders played at home last Saturday night, as they faced Liberty, the number one team in the district. Appomat tox was again overcome by a score of 69-36. In the first quarter, Enoch Robinson got 6 of the Raiders 8 points. Liberty had 20. Half time score was Liberty - 33, Appomattox - 15, as Enoch Robinson added 4 more, James Robinson - 2, and David Franklin - 1. The Raiders were held to a slim 5 points in the third quarter as it ended with Liberty on top, 52-20.

document.text: The Appomattox varsity Raiders ended their regular season last week with wins over - Brookviile and Bucking ham, and a loss to undefeated Amherst. Larry Kelso, who carried away game-scoring honors in all three games, stood poised on the brink of the 1,000-career-. points mark as the regular season ended, needing only 17 to break the magic four-figure line. Kelso stormed for 33 points Friday, as the Raiders took an easy 80-59 victory from haplera Brookviile, Kelso was joined In  the doublefigure scoring ranks by Terry Woods, who totaled 17 for the night, and by Shane Abernathy, who had ten points. The Raiders jumped to a 15-8 lead in the first quarter, and 1 never relinquished that ad vantage, leading 37-26 at the  half, 55-42 at the end of the third quarter, and 80-59 when the final buzzer sounded. The Raiders outshot Brook- L .  ville 28 field goals to 19, and hit 24 of 41 freethrows for a 56.5 percent average. W ith Kelso, Woods and A bernathy in the scoring column were Kim Humbles, who scored seven points, Steve Cobb with six points, Marvin Johnson who scored three, and David Pankey and John Simmons, with two points each.   Kelso and Abernathy led rebounders with 15 and 12 respectively, followed -fry Woods, who had 5 grabs. Buckingham was more of a challenge for the Raiders Wednesday night, with the load team holding through a - fourth-quarter rally to take the game, 61-49. Kelsos 19 points marked the games high scoring figure, followed by Buckinghams Marvin Lee 13 points, and Gary Woodson 12 points. document.text: Coach Howard Claboughs Raider varsity baseball team won three heart-stoppers last week to lift their record to 8-2, and place the local high school team firmly in first place ta the Seminole District. In a game played ta winter-like conditions Tuesday night, the Raiders defeated Altavista 54 in a game that went an extra inning. Altavista jumped to a 3-0 lead ta the first inning, but the Raiders came back ta the second inning to score two runs on a Greg Mayberry home run, and base hits by Tim Bennett and Alan Edmonds, which drove Paul Johnson across the plate. The Raiders tied the score at 3-3 ta the third inning after Mayberry walked, stole second, advanced to third base on a pass ball, and crossed the plate on Paul Johnsons grounder to short stop. Altavista went back out ta front ta the fourth inning, scoring one run on an error and a sacrifice fly. The Raiders tied the score ta the sixth inning when Tim Bennett walked, Edmonds singled, Jody Williams hit a fly ball to center and Rodney Bryant was hit by a pitch to load the bases. Gary Ferguson then walked, giving Tim Bennett a free pass across home plate. In the top of the eighth inning, the Raiders scored their final run of the game, when Edmonds got to first base on a fielders choice, and Williams hit a single advancing Edmonds to third base. Bryant then hit a sacrifice fly, scoring Edmonds. Altavista was unable to score ta their half of the inning. Leading hitters against Altavista were Edmonds two for four Bryant one for three, Mayberry one for three, one homer, Kevin Ferguson one for three, Bennett one for two and Jody Williams one for four. The Raiders knocked Liberty out of the first place ta the Seminole District ta a come-from-behtad effort Wednesday at Appomattox., The Raiders took the lead 1-0 ta the second inning, when Alan Edmonds hit a home run. The game was a Seminole District contest played at Grenta and left the Raiders 2-0 in the district and made them 3-1 overall. Glenn Doss got the Raiders on the scoreboard first as he went in from seven yards out  in the first quarter with 125  left in the quarter. Phillip Goode kicked the extra point to give the Raiders a 7-0 lead. The scoring opportunity was set up when Gretna fumbled on their own 43 and Mike Preston recovered the ball for the Raiders. It took Appomattox 11 plays to go the distance as Doss carried the ball 28 of the 43 yards. Neither team could do any damage in the second quarter as Appomattox did not gain a first down and Gretna did most of theirs passing. There was no scoring in the quarter and the Raiders took a 7-0 lead to the dressing room at the half. The Raiders made it 13-0 in the third quarter as they took a Gretna punt and started on their own 30. They moved the 70 yards in seven plays with Bobby Layne hitting Bill Austin with a pass for the last 27 yards and a touchdown. A pass for the two extra points failed and it was 13-0 with 659 left in the third quarter. Gretna came right back with a score with 223 left in the quarter to close tne gap to 13-0 as the extra point missed. Jerry Bond scored on a 7 yard run. At the start of the fourth quarter Layne again went into action as this time he threw a 51 yard scoring strike to Mike Gallier who made a beautiful catch falling and then regain ing his balance and going the rest of the distance untouched for the score. Phillip Goode kicked the point after with 1151 left in the game and it was 20-6. The drive had started in the third quarter on- the Appomattox 24 yard line. document.text: By BILL SHERROD Eight years is a long time to wait. Just ask anyone who follows Appo mattox County High School varsity football. But after eight years of playing an opponent, victory is sweet, andit was particularly succulent to the approximately 2,500 assem bled in Bragg Stadium Friday night when the Raiders defeated arch-foe Rustburg, 24-21. Summing up the essence of FridayTs game, coach Stuart Justus says, We outplayed them in the secoid half, thats all there is to it. A tenacious Raider defense held the Red Devils to a total of 30 yards offense in the second half, and the Devils executed only 18 plays on offense in the second half. Rustburg jumped out to an early two-touchdown advantage, and added a third score in the second quarter. But the Raiders narrowed the margin with three scores in the second quarter, on a one-yard plunge by quarterback Ke vin Ferguson, a 47-yard touchdown pass from Fer guson to Ernest Daye, and a 50-yard touchdown pass from Ferguson to Pete Mclvor. The score stood at 2118 as the first half ended. The Raider defense stif fened in the second half, and tailback Dennis Fleshmans 40-yard scamper into the end zone gave the home team the advantage as the game entered the home stretch. But, with time running out in the fourth- quarter, the Raiders let Red Devil Wellington Wheaton get around the right corner of the defense on a punt return, and the speedy Rustburg runner took the ball into the end zone. But alas, football is a game of breaks, and Wheatons scor ing run was canceled by a clipping penalty. I thought the game was pretty even as far as breaks go, Justus said in reference to the recalled touchdown. We did give them a touchdown in the first half the Devils scored one of their three touchdowns on a fumble recovery following a bad snap from center on a punt attem pt deep in Appomattox territory. The Raiders passing game surprised many at Fridays contest. Ferguson went five for 11 and 185 yards, including Ernest Dayes two receptions for 109 yards and a score, and Dennis Fleshmans two catches for 27 yards. Fleshman also led  the Raiders running game, carrying 19 times lor 132 yards. The Raiders got 15 first downs in the game, and Rustburg nine, including three on penalties. Were still making some mistakes, Justus said of his young tem. Penalties, players not being on the field when theyre supposed to be, are two examples. document.text: Appomattox Junior Varsity Raiders won their last game of the season Monday afternoon defeating Gretna 62-61 at Gre tna in a game postponed from Thursday because of snow. Coach Paris Lenon says that the win-loss column could have been better for this year, but another years experience will help the boys next year and that hes proud of the spirit of his team.
